awd_titl_txt: Symposium Title: Phenological Plasticity: from Molecular Mechanisms to Ecological and Evolutionary Implications
awd_abstract_narration:
The timing of life history events (e.g. timing of migration, reproduction, hibernation), collectively known as phenology, remains poorly understood in the wild. Ecologists have been challenged in their ability to explain current phenological patterns, as well as predict how such patterns may change as our global climate continues to warm. Recent advances in molecular ecology, physiology, and demography, coupled with the cumulation of long-term, individual-based studies of animals in the wild, will considerably improve our collective understanding of phenological shifts within the context of climate change. By bringing together researchers focused on different hierarchical levels of organization (from genes and molecules to organisms, populations and communities) and different taxonomic groups, we hope to stimulate inter-disciplinary discussion and collaboration within this emerging field. The symposium provides opportunities for early career scientists such as undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, assistant professors, and junior research scientists. Recognizing the importance of diverse perspectives, our speaker line-up brings in balanced gender representation and includes contributors from underrepresented groups. All speakers in the main symposium will be contributing a manuscript for publication in a special issue in the journal Integrative and Comparative Biology, the flagship journal of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology. In addition to publication of the results in ICB, we will broadly advertise and disseminate findings of the symposium via social media. 

Seasonal variation in the availability of essential resources is one of the most important drivers of natural selection on the phasing and duration of annually recurring life-cycle events. Shifts in seasonal timing are among the most commonly reported responses to climate change and the capacity of organisms to adjust their seasonal timing, either through phenotypic plasticity or microevolution, is a critical component of resilience. Despite growing interest in documenting and forecasting the impact of climate change on phenology, our ability to predict how individuals, populations, and species might respond in their timing of reproduction to changes in their environment is constrained by our limited knowledge regarding 1) the cues animals use to adjust timing, 2) the endogenous genetic and molecular mechanisms that transduce cues into neural and endocrine signals, and 3) the inherent capacity of animals to alter their timing and phasing within annual cycles. By bringing together researchers focused on different hierarchical levels of organization (from genes to organisms, populations and communities) and different taxonomic groups, we hope to stimulate inter-disciplinary collaborations around these themes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary. As part of the symposium titled “Phenological Plasticity: from Molecular Mechanisms to Ecological and Evolutionary Implications” presented at SICB 2022, the organization team was able to provide opportunities for speakers of varied career stages and from diverse disciplines to interact in-person and virtually, thus facilitating the development of new interdisciplinary collaborations to investigate the causes and consequences of climate-driven phenological shifts (e.g. changes in the timing of reproduction, hibernation, migration in wild animals). Through various presentations and symposium publications, participants were able to identify the components that contribute to individual, population, and community resilience to shifting phenology. Participants discussed new approaches and generated new hypotheses by engaging a diverse group of contributors in both the main and complementary sessions. By bringing together molecular, physiological, ecological, and evolutionary perspectives, the group was able to stimulate cross-disciplinary dialogue. Amidst the challenges posed by Omicron at the time, we still managed to succeed in achieving the following objectives the organizers had set out: 1)   Speakers submitted and published a manuscript based on their talk in Integrative and Comparative Biology; 2) Published papers addressing either how integration across levels of organization or the development of new tools/methods to move the field forward. 3) The symposium participants were satisfied with their symposium experience.

 

Intellectual merit. Through a series of presentations and manuscript, the participants have been able to Identify the components that contribute to individual, population, and community resilience to shifting phenology. The group was also able to determine future directions for the field, including identifying new approaches and generating new hypotheses by engaging a diverse group of contributors. Presentations and manuscripts ranged many taxa, environmental contexts, disciplines, and covered a wide breadth of concepts centered on phenological plasticity. The symposium included a general overview (i.e. “Phenological Plasticity: from Molecular Mechanisms to Ecological and Evolutionary Implications           “); empirical studies based both on field and lab data collection (e.g., “Integrating across lab and field to understand the flexibility of annual biological timekeeping Cue integration in the timing of annual cycle events”); the evolutionary mechanisms at play in shaping phenology (e.g. “Environmental and genetic determinants of variation in reproductive phenology in North American red squirrels”); the environmental context and its role in shaping phenology across diverse taxa (e.g. “Phenological plasticity under climate change: the critical role of microhabitat diversity”); as well as more theoretical and grounding contributions (e.g. “Phenological patterns and their evolution on a cyclical Earth”). The complementary session also contributed a more mechanistic understanding of shifts in seasonal timing (e.g. “Seasonal programs in body mass despite stable blood chemistry for energy homeostasis in the Siberian hamster”). The vast majority of speakers contributed a manuscript for publication in a special issue in the journal Integrative and Comparative Biology (ICB), the flagship journal of the Society for ICB, to be published as part of a special issue in August 2022.

 

Broader Impacts. The symposium provided opportunities for early career scientists – invited speakers include postdocs, assistant professors, and junior research scientists. The complimentary session targeted (under)graduate students and postdocs. The organizers provided opportunities for speakers of varied career stages and from diverse disciplines to interact on site and through the virtual symposium, thus facilitating the development of new interdisciplinary collaborations to investigate the causes and consequences of climate-driven phenological shifts. Indeed, the following presenters and authors were able to partake in all symposium activities, either in-person or remotely due to travel restrictions imposed by the Omicron health crisis:

  • Pilar Fuentes –  Undergraduate (Colby College): Heritability and regulation of plasticity in a sexually competitive trait.
  • Andrea Wishart – PhD Candidate (University of Saskatchewan): Capital gains: investigating the influence of current cached resources on annual resource acquisition in a food-caching wild mammal.
  • Dr. Victor Zhang –  Postdoctoral Fellow (University of Washington): Accelerometry reveals the temporal niches of the island fox and island spotted skunk.

Recognizing the importance of diverse perspectives, our speaker line-up brought in balanced gender representation and included contributors from underrepresented groups. We were also able to include international perspectives to this symposium and had speakers from institutions in Canada, the United Kingdom, Israel, and Norway participate in the symposium:

  • Dr. Ofir Levy - Phenological plasticity under climate change: the critical role of microhabitat diversity 
  • Dr. John Park - Cyclical fluctuations in the environment and their role in shaping life histories 
  • Dr. Heather Watts - Cue integration in the timing of annual cycle events
  • Dr. Jeffrey Lane - Environmental and genetic determinants of variation in reproductive phenology in North American red squirrels.

In addition to the presentation and publication of the results in ICB, the symposium was broadly advertised and disseminated findings via social media (#SICB). Omicron considerably affected our ability to interact in-person through this symposium but all of the exciting virtual and in-person presentations stimulated discussions that continue past SICB22.


Last Modified: 06/17/2022
Modified by: Lise M Aubry
